On Tuesday, November 4, 2003, at 4:09:11 PM, Timothy Wall wrote:

> On Tuesday, November 4, 2003, at 01:49 PM, Ron Jeffries wrote:
>> On Tuesday, November 4, 2003, at 1:44:42 PM, Dave Astels wrote:
>>> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "ljb114ca" <ljb114ca@y...> wrote:
>>>> Can some give me a liitle suggestions how to solve the Eight Queens
>>>> problem with TDD method?
>>
>>> Why?  There's well documented solutions.  Look it up.
>>
>>> I had a short discussion with <I forget> at OOPSLA last week about the
>>> recurring questions of "how would I evolve <insert well known
>>> algorithm here> using TDD".  Well.. you don't have to... it's well
>>> known.. just use it.  Write a few tests to make sure you have it typed
>>> in correctly and that it keeps working.. but I see no reason to evolve
>>> algorithms I learned in University from a text.
>>
>> Might be good exercise, though.

> Especially if you're trying to prove to yourself that the method either 
> will or will not work, or (assuming it will) that you're using it 
> correctly to lead you to the known result.  Certainly a valid control 
> experiment before trying it in the wild :)

Yes. Although the 8 Queens problem isn't really much about programming, and
is a lot about conceptualizing. I think it's a good exercise, but perhaps
not the best for "proving" whether TDD works.

Ron Jeffries
www.XProgramming.com
